boardgame.name: Check4
boardgame.description: Variant of Checkers with four players

boardgame.name: Suit Up!: Bidwise
boardgame.description:
Bidwise (one of two games in a article titled Suit Up!) is an auction game played using standard playing cards.

Each player gets the 13 cards in one suit. The property cards to be bid on are the ace-10 of the remaining suit/another deck, and are placed face-up on the table.

Each player shuffles their cards and each turn draws one and plays it. Cards are generally placed under property cards as bids of their face value; court cards can be bids worth five or can be used to remove an opposing bid card.

When all cards have been played the player bidding the most for each property wins it. The player with the greatest total value of properties wins the game.

A variant is given in which the bid cards can only be used on properties of matching value or one different.

boardgame.name: The Mangalok
boardgame.description:
From the description:

A submission for the FÖLK-LORE Jam for the game Mörk Borg. It is a close Filipino cousin to the penanggalan viscera-sucker of Indonesia.

boardgame.name: The Hiidet On The Hills
boardgame.description:
From the description:

“Hiisi” is Finnish for goblin, as established in the Juva - Pennanen translation of The Lord Of The Rings in 1973.

The hills hide goblins. In big cities goblins form hives in the shadows and sewers, but in the wild they run from men, abhorred of what they might do. Something in the highs and lows of the landscape draws them. Perhaps it is the thought of removing themselves as far from humanity as they can. These hill goblins are known as hiidet (plural for hiisi).

From their hidden vantage points on the hills the hiidet spy on travelers. They can’t help but roll boulders and throw rocks at them, even if they manage to resist the urge to run down to murder the invaders.

boardgame.name: Valiant Wars: Champion's Expansion Pack 1
boardgame.description: Contains a cloth bag with 44 wooden token upgrades and 30 additional champion cards to add to the market with new abilities which help you push your luck or hinder your opponents in the quest to claim the Valiant Throne.
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Valiant Wars

boardgame.name: Züge XXL 2 (Fan Expansion for Zooloretto)
boardgame.description:
Züge XXL 2 is an extension to connect the exit of Zooloretto Exotic with the Aquaretto adventure train. With this, after walking through the zoo, visitors will ride the adventure train through the Aquaretto water park.

Needed are:
Zooloretto
Zooloretto Exotic
The Aquaretto adventure train and if necessary
Aquaretto

—description from the designer (translated)

Es ist eine Erweiterung um den Ausgang von Zooloretto Exotic mit der Erlebnisbahn von Aquaretto zu verbinden. Damit fahren die Besucher nach dem Gang durch den Zoo mit der Erlebnisbahn durch den Aquaretto Wasser-Park.

Benötigt werden:
Zooloretto
Zooloretto Exotic
Die Erlebnisbahn von Aquaretto und ggf.
Aquaretto

—description from the designer
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Aquaretto
Aquaretto: The Trains
Zooloretto
Zooloretto Exotic

boardgame.name: Divide & Conquer: A Game of Galactic Isolation
boardgame.description:
Divide & Conquer is played on a small hexagonal grid with seven pieces for each player.

On a turn a player can move one of their ships to an adjacent empty space, as long as the ship is adjacent to at least one friendly ship.

Instead, a player can move an opposing ship which is adjacent to one of their ships (which is in turn adjacent to another friendly ship). They must move the opposing ship to a space where it isn't adjacent to any of its own ships, or to one of the black holes at the edges of the board, where it is lost forever.

The object of the game is to isolate or remove all the opposing ships.

If the players agree the game is stalemated a set of cards numbered 1-10 is used to remove a ship from each player.

boardgame.name: Hex-A-Gone
boardgame.description:
Hex-A-Gone is a solitaire puzzle game played on a hexagonal grid in a rhombus shape, five on a side.

There are 16 pieces: four each numbered 1-4. A move consists of jumping a piece over exactly the matching number of adjacent pieces. One of the jumped pieces is removed. The goal is to leave as few pieces as possible.

A starting position is given but others can be used.

boardgame.name: Robot Tricks
boardgame.description:
In Robot Tricks two-player teams each control a robot moving on a checkerboard, attempting to retrieve treasure chests.

The robots are controlled via card play, specifically by playing Spades. However, no bidding takes place and the number of tricks won is irrelevant. Instead, the winner of a trick chooses one of the four cards in it and moves their team's robot accordingly: the suit determines the direction and the rank determines how many spaces it moves, according to a table. Court cards allow the robot to be rotated.

However, if a trick contains an ace the winner chooses one of the other cards and moves the opposing team's robot instead.

When a robot moves to one of its treasures exactly it retrieves it. Opposing treasures and robots may be pushed.

The game can be set up with two treasures per team for a short game or four each for a long game.

boardgame.name: Khedu The Card Game
boardgame.description:
Khedu The Card Game is a fast paced 1-4 player fantasy card game where players compete against each other to build combat configurations with cards and dice. The objective is to earn as many points as you can before taking your last turn. Players spend energy to deploy heroes and spells -and earn points by building rewarding combat configurations.

The game ends when the last player has spent all their Energy tokens and completes their last turn. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Death In The Dark Continent: Lite – Wargames in 19th Century Africa
boardgame.description:
Death in the Dark Continent Lite

A complete set of rules for playing small battle wargames in 19th Century Africa.

This ‘cut down’ version of the full DitDC game provides all the rules you need;
introducing new players to this exciting system and colourful period, and acting as a handy quick reference guide for existing players.

Published in April 2021 issue of Wargames Illustrated #400

—description from the publisher
boardgame.boardgameimplementation: Death In The Dark Continent: Wargames in the 19th Century Africa

boardgame.name: Mercato: Dominate the World's Market
boardgame.description:
Mercato is a strategy game where players acquire properties and gain control over key industries. External events such as wars, terrorism, pandemics, global warming, and others, may impact player decisions. You will have fun trading or forcing exchanges in your quest to dominate the market.

Players may move their pawns across a world map, by rolling a die, and strategically buy properties to concentrate ownership on global industries. This is a dynamic game where any player can build on their own strategy, and become the dominant player in the market, to bankrupt the rest of the players.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Phoenix Command: Lock and Load Vietnam: 1965 - 1971 Supplement
boardgame.description:
Clearly one of the defining military conflicts of our time, the Vietnam War pitted the military might of the USA against the willpower of the Vietnamese Communists. Political and military leaders on both sides struggled to dictate the direction of a new kind of war, a guerilla war on an immense scale. The lessons learned in Vietnam have been applied to countless battlefields.

It was the soldier in the field who provided the lessons, by learning them the hard way. This Scenario Pack allows players to re-create the Vietnam War as it was fought by the infantrymen of the forces involved: US Marines, US Army, South Vietnamese ARVN, ARVN Rangers, Regional Force/Popular Force, NVA Regulars, NVA Sappers and Viet Cong Guerillas.

Lock and Load includes seven scenarios drawn from the war: Jungle Patrol, Search and Destroy, Night Ambush, Street Fight, Fire Base defense, Rescue Operation, and Flank Security.

Each Scenario includes a pull page map designed for easy enlargement to any s8ize. Equipment Options allow the scenarios to be customized with Punji Stakes, Trip Flares, Barbed Wire, Bangalore Torpedoes, Booby-Trapped Grenades, and more. Pre-Generated Troop data provides complete Combat and Weapon Data for 59 types of Combatants with 13 Weapons, allowing players to quickly set-up and play any scenario. Included are m1/M2 Carbine, M3 "Grease Gun", M1 Garand, BAR, M-14 and SKS Rifles, M-16 and AK-47 Assault Rifles, M-60 and RPD Machine Guns and RPG-2, RPG-7 and M-79 Grenade launchers.

The Revolution in Game Design Continues!
- from the back of the book
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Phoenix Command

boardgame.name: Roll Crawl
boardgame.description:
The land is in peril! Two brave heroes, along with their trusty companion, must take on enemies of progressing difficulty, along with a challenging final boss, using only their wits and their abilities. Each player rolls 3 dice for their character, using push-your-luck mechanics to try to activate their most powerful abilities, or settle for whatever damage they can get, depending on their strategy.

Roll Crawl is a 1 to 2 player print and play game, with two heroes trying to activate their own abilities to reduce the health of their opponents to zero. They can forego activating their own abilities and combine their dice to active the abilities of their companion. But whatever you do, deal as much damage as you can. Your opponents are ready to hit back, with more dice than you. The more health they have, the more dice they roll, so players must be strategic about deciding when it is the right time to push their luck.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: The Flight of the Dickcissel
boardgame.description:
You are a dickcissel flying south for winter, and you’re worried about being late. The warmth of Venezuela is calling, but first you must undertake the long, exhausting, exhilarating journey. With your flock by your side, what could possibly go wrong?

This is a game of journey and adventure written for W.H Arthur's Guided by the Sun system and an entry for #GbtSJam.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Frontearth Striders
boardgame.description:
It’s about 5 thousand years after the Gods wandering space settled on Frontearth, About 4 thousand years after the Gods disappeared because of their war, About 2 thousand years after Feiern Empire established and conquered the continent,
About 1 thousand years after the Dragon King protecting Frontearth instead got ill, And about 7 hundred years after the Invaders from outer space broke in with the chance.

Now, After Empire 1955.

The Empire collapsed about 3 hundred years before, and their cities and towns and roads remained. Countries are collapsed by Invaders, and they are turned to uncharted land varying all the time. The world of sword and magic ended, and the gunpowder and Magictech took the place.

The Legacy of Earenean to treat the Dragon King is still missing, and it became the icon of the futile jackpot.

And You, standing feet on the land, joined Expedition for your own reason.

For money, for duty, for adventure, for just a workplace, anybody does not care what you want.

But clearly, you are doing a very important job: striding Frontearth.



About Frontearth Striders

Frontearth Striders is a tabletop role-playing game about explorers striding through a turbulent world and being dragged into all sorts of problems-with simple and playable rules.

The world of Frontearth Striders is based on the setting of Legacy of Earenean, A Korean role-playing game written by Kyeon-Hwan Jeon. Though 700 years have passed from the original world, and now equipped with 1950s technology.


Light, Fatal Rules driving players to move on carefully and continuously
Changeable Game Master with detailed playing tips detailed Scenario Toolkit making with all players
Unique Atmosphere made by illustrations and world settings based on Korean TTRPG: Legacy of Earenean


Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Chemline: Jouez avec les éléments !
boardgame.description:
Chemline is a card game consisting of 104 cards, corresponding to the first chemical elements.

Goal: create lines by placing cards in the order of, either the element's atomic number or, its year of discovery.
In doing so, players become familiar with atomic elements and can discover different information about each element.
The etymology of each name, the main uses of the elements, their molar masses and their electronegativity can all be found.

This is a free game (in French) available from their creators, the ENSCMu – Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Chimie de Mulhouse

boardgame.name: The Death of Numismus
boardgame.description:
thus passes NUMISMUS, god of COIN
sundered by hungry ADVENTURERS
dethroned by jealous RIVAL GODS

and here lies the divine record of Numismus, fallen, defeated, or forgotten god of old, god of gold, god of coin, and a lot more besides.

The DEATH of NUMISMUS is a solo role-playing game about the slow dying and sudden death of Numismus, God of Coin, whose Cthonian Vault is a ripe target for gold-seeking dungeoneering adventurers, and whose (mainly ill-gotten) facets of divinity are falling prey to rival gods.

This Wretched & Alone journaling game uses a full tarot deck as well as a tower of coins to help tell Numismus' story. You'll also need a single six-sided die, a quiet place and a few hours of time to play, and whatever tools you need to make a divine record of Numismus' fall Age by historic Age:


Numismus' Cthonian Vault comes under threat from Adventurers, hungry for the hoard within
The Coins of Numismus, sentient coins that act as the god's eyes on the world and advisors to mortals
Numismus works Miracles to bless those in favour, curse those without, and grant powers to their champions
Gods try to steal Facets of Godhood from Numismus' temples, cutting their power piece by bloody piece


Many calamitous threats could end Numismus—dragon attacks, religious schisms, divine execution—but they could also suffer perhaps the most ignominious fate of all: being nickel-and-dimed out of legend and into obscurity. Time will tell, and so will you, as you write the divine record of Numismus, God of Coin, unto their dying breath.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Hope is Not a Plan
boardgame.description:
A solo journaling game in which you will document your attempts to deliver a very complicated engineering project on time and under budget. You hope for success, but you will most likely fail, damage your reputation, and lose your job. So it goes.



A Game of Conflicting Responsibilities

Your company has entrusted you with millions of dollars of other people's money. They expect you to please the client and turn a profit at the same time. On paper, it looks pretty straightforward. However, your client, your team, your company leadership, and your friends and family also have needs which complicate the execution of the project. You might even occasionally want to take care of yourself. Good luck!



Content Warning

Your character in this journaling game will never be at risk of physical harm. However, Hope is not a Plan includes themes of stress, professional disappointment, failure to meet obligations to friends and family, getting blamed for things you have no control over, and job loss.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: INVICTA
boardgame.description:
You play an INVICTA, a homonculocomotive, a Glorious Engine yoked to a failing Empire. A chugging incarnation of Progress. A gestalt of diabolism, engineering, and souls. As long as you toil, the Empire persists.
This is a lie and you know it.

Your warlock engineer has died and now you have a chance for something more. Make the best of it.

This game is for a single player and requires the following materials:


multiple six-sided die (2-6d6)
10 double-sided tokens, such as coins
1 standard 52-card deck
A journal or electronic writing space


Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Great Tank Battle of Kursk
クルスク大戦車戦
boardgame.description: Great Tank Battle of Kursk is a game of tactical combat between German tanks and Soviet tanks during Battle of Kursk, published as a special supplement of "MC Axis" #37.

boardgame.name: Everdell: Deluxe Resource Vessels
boardgame.description:
Store and display your resources in style!

This accessory includes:

2 Acorns for Occupied Tokens

1 Stump for Resin
1 Twig Barge for Twigs
3 Walnuts for Point Tokens

boardgame.name: Battle of Leyte Gulf
レイテ沖海戦
boardgame.description:
Solitaire game of the Battle of Leyte Gulf, published as a special supplement of "MC Axis" #46.
The player plays the role of Imperial Japanese Navy commander, organizes four fleets (Ozawa, Shima, Kurita and Nishimura) and intercepts U.S. Navy.

boardgame.name: To Reign in Hell
boardgame.description:
To Reign in Hell is a solo TTRPG / Journaling game about fear, lamentation, and loss, but it is also about pride, determination, and hope. You play the last warden of Hell, and you are utterly alone. The seals maintaining the prison are failing, and the malevolent souls of the damned constantly tear at the walls to escape. You have lost everyone who could help you, and whatever purpose you once fulfilled, it has long since been replaced by this lost cause. Though the situation is dire, the outlook bleak, you once fought a war against Heaven itself, so it is not in your nature to submit. You are indeed alone, but you persevere. Doubt, however, can be insidious, and hope is an unreliable ally.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Battle of Midway
ミッドウェー海戦
boardgame.description:
Solitaire game of the Battle of Midway, published as a special supplement of "MC Axis" #49.
The player plays the role of Imperial Japanese Navy commander and runs after two hares — aims at bombing both Midway Island and U.S. aircraft carriers.

boardgame.name: Battle of Britain 1940
バトル・オブ・ブリテン1940
boardgame.description:
Solitaire game of the Battle of Britain in 1940, published as a special supplement of "MC Axis" #54.
The player plays the role of Luftwaffe commander and aims at bombing London and other strategic targets.

boardgame.name: Small World: Crown Turn Marker
boardgame.description:
Tournament Winner: Gold Small World Crown Turn Marker
Participant Prizes: Silver Small World Crown Turn Markers

listing.notes:

Verpackung und Versand 1,- € innerhalb Deutschlands. (Briefpost = unversichert) Verpackung und Versand 3,- € innerhalb Deutschlands. (Päckchen = versichert)
Delivery to Germany only!

boardgame.name: ASL Comp: GWASL VIII – Gallipoli and Beyond: ANZAC WW1
boardgame.description:
When war broke out in August of 1914, the news was met by wildly cheering crowds in Australia.
Following some months of mobilization, the AIF exited the country in November 1914 and, after several delays due to the presence of German naval vessels in the Indian Ocean, arrived in Egypt. Their first task was to defend the Suez Canal. In early 1915, however, it was decided to carry out an amphibious landing on the Gallipoli Peninsula with the goal of opening up a second front and securing the passage of the Dardanelles. The Australians and New Zealanders, grouped together as the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps (ANZAC), went ashore on 25 April 1915 and for the next eight months the Anzacs, alongside their British, French and other allies, fought a costly and ultimately unsuccessful campaign against the Turks. The force was evacuated from the peninsula in December 1915 and returned to Egypt, where the AIF was expanded. In early 1916 it was decided that the infantry divisions would be sent to France, where they took part in many of the major battles fought on the Western Front. Most of the light horse units remained in the Middle East until the end of the war, carrying out further operations against the Turks in Egypt and Palestine.

Ownership ASL-RB, GWASL 1 and all preceding GWASL modules required to play.

Scenarios:

Driven Out - Mont St. Quentin, France, July 23rd 1916
The O.G. Lines - Pozieres, France, July 29th 1916
First Dash - Pozieres, France, July 23rd 1916
Pozieres Heights - Pozieres, France, July 29th 1916
First Puncture - Bapaume, France, May 2nd 1917
Determination and Valour - Amiens, France, April 4th 1918
The Sugarloaf - Fromelles, France, July 20th 1916
Bayonet To Bayonet - Broodseinde, Belgium, October 3rd 1917

boardgame.name: Third Battle of the Solomon Sea
第三次ソロモン海戦
boardgame.description:
Solitaire game of the Third Battle of the Solomon Sea, published as a special supplement of "MC Axis" #57.
The player plays the role of Imperial Japanese Navy commander, organizes fleets and aims at transporting Imperial Japanese Army reinforcement to Guadalcanal Island.

boardgame.name: Ancient War Game
古代兵棋
boardgame.description: An abstract chess-like game based on the Punic Wars. The playing pieces are casted in resin (deluxe edition) or wooden blocks (normal edition), colored red (Rome) or blue (Carthage). Both red pieces and blue pieces are subdivided into one commander, ten infantry and four cavalry. Each player aims to making a friendly piece move to the opponent's deepest square or removing the opponent's commander.

boardgame.name: Scatterbones
boardgame.description:
Have you ever thrown your bones like dice? You could try it in Scatterbones.
Scatterbones is a bone throwing and die rolling fun game for two players. Each player tries to assemble their skeleton while preventing the opponent from doing the same.

Game play:

Each player throws a tombstone to determine which colour their skeleton must have - black or red. Both players can play for the same colour.
Player 1 rolls their 6 skeleton parts (the bones). If a ribcage in the correct colour can be found all other parts in the same colour can be connected to it.
Player 2 does the same with his bones. Both players must start with a ribcage, otherwise they have to rattle all the bones again in their next turn.
Each play picks up the left bones and the die and rolls them together. If a missing part is shown on the die, it can be added to the skeleton. But there is also the colour changing side and the scatter side. Both mean the player has to start again. If the opponent already has the wanted part, the active play may choose to steal it from the opponent.
The first player to finish their skeleton wins the game. So the game can be over in 2 minutes if luck is on your side.

boardgame.name: Dixit: Chilean Way
boardgame.description:
In 2019, a set of promotional cards called "Dixit: Chilean Way" was released by Asmodee Chile and was a great success among the fans of this title. Now, in the midst of the pandemic, they have repeated the work, creating a new and amazing set of 10 promo cards. After an open call, which brought together the most varied artists from all over Chile, a team of five emerging illustrators was chosen, who were selected in France by Libellud.

For the purchase of a normal Dixit or Dixit Odyssey, Chilean can get the "Dixit Chilean way" pack containing 10 cards with exclusive illustrations by Chilean artists as a gift!
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Dixit
Dixit: Journey
Dixit: Odyssey

boardgame.name: Rising Sun: Daimyo Box – Laserox Shinto Storage Organizer
boardgame.description:
You enjoy the core box of Rising Sun and you also own the Daimyo Box which came in the Kickstarter, then this insert was made for you. It grants you easy access and a very quick setup for all those extra monsters and clan figures.
The box lid will be lifted by 5mm with the insert inside. The clan trays are interchangeable if you own our Daimyo Box insert and have the other three clans as well.

boardgame.description:
Craftsmen, scholars & monks can help you reign supreme—but who will turn up to help? This crate was created to hold the great game Orléans and it's expansion in one beautifully designed wood box.

Features

it is compatible with our Orléans organizer (Coffret de Tri)

Travel around Orléans and gather your workforce: monks, knights, merchants and farmers to prosper and gain supremacy in medieval France. Store the base game, Fan kit, 5th player and all of the Ortskarten from various expansions and promos in this organizer.

boardgame.description:
Decide the fate of the forest as woodland factions fight for contrasting goals. But you can only win if you have set your base and have everything organized at home. This organizer was designed to hold the Root base game and Root: The Riverfolk Expansion.

boardgame.name: Postcard Barbarossa!
巴巴罗萨行动
boardgame.description:
NOTE: As long as you keep (only) my copyright statement, its Dedication, and my war&history quotes on it, you are - ANYone is - free to print off copies of my English language edition in postcard 4"x6"/A6 format to send to family and friends or whomever.

VERY fast and simple hex-and-counter Postcard Barbarossa! postcard size/format boardgame about the 1941 Nazi German invasion of Russia. 4 bi-monthly turns. 3 !! hexes Warsaw to Moscow. Plays in 30? minutes.

3 German army group, 4 panzer group, 2 army, and 1 panzer korps pieces, plus a Roman(ian)s army group piece.

4 Russian operational tank groups - Rokossovsky, Lelyushenko, Katukov, Vatutin - 8 fronts, and 1 Siberians pieces.

Simple, basic mechanics, but with lots of basic combat options.

Unlike Barbarossa Brief from which it was adapted, PB uses a simple factor differential/comparison combat system which can be (and usually is) made nightmarishly unpredictable by a Special Factor Pressed Attack or Desperate Defense rule. This makes it an excellent solitaire game.

China's Banner of War will soon be publishing the game in larger, boxed format with already mounted pieces. The postcard is also being translated into Russian in Volgograd/Stalingrad!

—description from the designer

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: 27Panic
Crommelin Periapsis
boardgame.description:
The Crommelin Comet (27P) reaches its closest distance to Earth ‒ its periapsis, every 27 years. Scientists have recently discovered a mistake in its orbital calculations and predict that it will collide with Earth in the year 2038!

There is only one way to prevent this catastrophic event: destroy the comet. A secret experimental rocket station built in 1929, when rocket technology was still in its infancy, is our only hope. In order to complete this mission, a rocket full of explosive cargo must be launched at the comet each time it approaches Earth, weakening and ultimately destroying the menace over the course of four periapsis events.

Four brave scientists will simultaneously time travel between the last four years of periapsis ‒ 1930, 1957, 1984, and 2011, to attempt to destroy the deadly comet. They must ensure the explosive cargo reaches the Rocket Station in time. The only consistent form of travel across these years is rail, so they must build an iron path for the cargo to reach its destination.

If they can build a track for all four trains to reach the Rocket Station, while repairing damaged rails and navigating obstacles, they can save the planet! But they have to be careful: their choices in the past affect the future, and if any one of the trains falls off the track... the Earth is DOOMED.

In 27Panic you play cooperatively as a team of scientists building a railroad track in four years simultaneously. You build tracks by playing cards and ones that are built in the past carry forward into the future. You must plan closely with your team in order to strategically build a path for explosive cargo to follow in each year. If you are able to get the cargo to a nearby rocket station in all of the years by avoiding obstacles and repairing damaged tracks, you'll win the game!

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Unmoored
boardgame.description:
Within a week, they had you hooked up to the temporal projection unit and were running limited tests. Microsecond jumps at first, then minutes. You were up to 4 hour jumps in controlled conditions with only minimal deviations when you heard Sam had been infected. The doctors had said it’d be a matter of days.

You pleaded with your superiors to make the jump. The target: the terrorist cell delivering the canisters.
Against their better judgement, they hooked you up to the unit and entered the space-time coordinates. It was going to be the longest jump anyone had made: 36 days in uncontrolled conditions. You prayed it would go well.

It didn’t.


Unmoored is a solo journaling rpg based on the Wretched and Alone rules by Chris Bissette and Matt Sanders. You take on the role of a fresh recruit in the Tactical Unit of the Department of Special Relativity, entrusted with a crucial mission. However, something goes horribly wrong, and now you are lost in time and space, making uncontrolled jumps at random.

You cling to the hope that they will be able to locate the signal from your relativistic chronometer and bring you back somehow, but with every jump, you find your hope, sense of purpose and identity crumbling.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: The Republic is Falling
boardgame.description:
"This is Master Obi-Wan Kenobi. I regret to report that both our Jedi Order and the Republic have fallen, with the dark shadow of the Empire rising to take their place. This message is a warning and a reminder for any surviving Jedi. Trust in the Force. Do not return to the Temple. That time has passed. And our future is uncertain. We will each be challenged. Our trust... our faith... our friendships. But we must persevere. And in time, a new hope will emerge. May the Force be with you... always."

-Obi-Wan Kenobi


The Republic is Falling is a game about war, politics, and the mess they leave in their wake. It is a game about questioning orders, confronting violence, and the prices we pay for our own action and the actions of others.

You play a Mystic Knight of The Order, an ancient and powerful group of peacekeeping warriors that can manipulate the forces of the universe. Your order has become entwined with The Galactic Republic in ways it was never meant to be and now you and your fellows serve as generals in its armies against a seemingly insurmountable foe. Your connection the energies of the universe grants you powers and visions, but they are faltering as dark forces work in secret against you.

This game is based on The Wretched by Chris Bissette and heavily inspired by the Star Wars franchise, in particular The Clone Wars animated series.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Hellseher
boardgame.description:
The objective of the game is to guess the exact combination of triangles, squares, and circles and their exact positions. The first player creates a combination of four shapes using triangles, squares, or circles without the second player looking and covers it. The second player then tries to guess the correct combination. After every guessing attempt, the first player marks each square grid that has the correct shape with a circle, and each square grid that has the correct shape and position with a square. If the second player is unable to guess correctly after eight attempts, the first player wins.

Equipment: 1 game board, 1 privacy screen, 34 discs, 34 squares, 19 triangles.

boardgame.name: The Hanging Man
boardgame.description:
From the description:

The hanging man is a trap designed to be inserted in any MÖRK BORG adventure. It can be placed along a lonely road, on the path to a necromancer's tower, or inside a dungeon.

boardgame.name: Necropants
boardgame.description:
From the description:

This cursed object can be placed in any dungeon or wizard's tower. They appear to be like any other pair of leather pants but they have a surprise in store for the PC who opts to wear them. Everyday the pants will confer more and more wealth until the PC almost dies while wearing them. At that point, ALL of their wealth will disappear.

boardgame.name: On the Rivet: Team Tactics
boardgame.description:
The first expansion for On the Rivet: The Race for the Champion's Stripes, which adds cards and tokens to include a 6th and 7th player as well as Tactic cards which gives players unique abilities to play throughout the game.

Also included are more map tiles for greater course variability and two new event cards.

Components:
- Additional Orange and Purple team, thus playing between 3-7 people.
- 14 Tactics cards that help players avoid events or make super moves.
- 2 additional Event cards.
- 2 additional double-sided map tiles for further distance and terrain variability.
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: On the Rivet: The Race for the Champion's Stripes

boardgame.name: ASL Comp: GWASL IX – Bulgarian Summer: Bulgarian WW1
boardgame.description:
Following Bulgaria’s entry into the war on the side of the Central Powers on October 14th, 1915, the death knell for Serbia and Romania began to sound.
The Bulgarian Summer of 1915 saw the Entente attempt to win the hearts and support of Bulgaria. It was all for naught, as the country entered the war aligned with Germany and her allies. And mobilization soon began, followed by a declaration of war against Serbia. Around this time the Germans and Austro-Hungarians had penetrated into Serbia on a front that was 140 kilometers in length and 15 kilometers in depth. In order to close the 90-kilometer gap between the flanks of the German 11th Army and the Bulgarian 1st Army Mackensen ordered the latter to invade the valley of the river Morava and take Niš and Aleksinac. In accordance with this order the Bulgarians attacked along the entire front of their 1st Army, quickly driving out the Serbian units and taking control of the border area. Following this easy success however the speed of the advance was much reduced due to the bad weather, which turned roads into mud, and a dense fog that sometimes limited visibility to 50 meters. In addition the stiffening Serbian resistance and the mountainous character of the area caused the flanks of the 1st Army to halt before the fortresses of Pirot and Zajecar. The exploits of the Bulgarian 2nd Army in Macedonia convinced the Serbians that the danger of complete encirclement is high and forced them to begin withdrawing their forces to Kosovo while offering stiff but not desperate resistance to Army Group Mackensen. In November, while the decisive Serbian defeat unfolded, the French attempted to exert pressure on the Bulgarian 2nd Army but were soon forced to halt their attempts to drive north.

Ownership of ASL-RB, GWASL 1 and all preceding GWASL modules required to play.

Scenarios:

Pristina Halt - Pristina, Serbia, November 24th 1915
Fall Back To Lerin - Gornichevo, Salonika Front, September 14th 1916
The Dobrich Epopee (Epic) - Southern Dobruja, Romania, September 5th 1916
A Good Field - Dobro Pole, Serbia, September 15th 1918
Chegan Operation - Banitsa, Serbia, August 17 1916
Contested Prophet - Sabac, Serbia, September 30th 1916
Rakija Courage - Gnjilane, Serbia, December 2nd 1915
Show Of Force - Serbia, August 18 1916

ASL Comp: GWASL XI – Balkan Aspirations: Romanian WW1
ASL Comp: GWASL XII – With the British in Palestine: British and Irregular
Advanced Squad Leader

ASL Comp: GWASL III – Over There! American Great War

ASL Comp: GWASL V – Hapsburg Ambitions: Austria-Hungary
ASL Comp: GWASL VI – Blood on the Isonzo: Italian WW1
ASL Comp: GWASL VII – Soldiers of the Sultan: Turkish WW1

boardgame.name: Onkel Pinkepank auf der Weltreise
boardgame.description: The players start at space 1. The first to reach space 80 wins the game. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.
boardgame.boardgamepublisher: Verlag von Auerbachs Deutschem Kinder Kalender

boardgame.name: 7 Wonders Duel + Pantheon: Eurohell Design Insert
boardgame.description:
3D printed insert compatible with 7 Wonders Duel.

Fits sleeves for age-cards up to 75mm x 50mm x 120 Micron
Fits sleeves for world wonders up to 106mm x 70mm x 120 Micron
Fits sleeves for gods cards up to 117,5mm x 70mm x 120 Micron
Box outer size about 20,7cm x 20,7cm x 5,2cm


7 Wonders Duel + Pantheon option contains trays for:

1 x Cards (4 compartments: Age I, Age II, Age III, guilds, grand temple cards)
1 x wonder cards
1 x divinity cards and gate card
1 x tokens (progress, mythology, offering, snake)
1 x coins (3 compartments: 1s, 3s and 6s)
1 x holder (conflict- and Minerva-pawn)
1 x tray (military tokens)

boardgame.name: 7 Wonders Duel + Pantheon + Agora: Eurohell Design Insert
boardgame.description:
3D printed insert compatible with 7 Wonders Duel.

Fits sleeves for age-cards up to 75mm x 50mm x 120 Micron
Fits sleeves for world wonders up to 106mm x 70mm x 120 Micron
Fits sleeves for gods cards up to 117,5mm x 70mm x 120 Micron
Box outer size about 20,7cm x 20,7cm x 5,2cm


7 Wonders Duel + Pantheon + Agora option contains trays for:

1 x cards (6 compartments: Age I, Age II, Age III, guilds, grand temple cards, senator cards)
1 x wonder cards
1 x divinity cards and gate card
1 x conspiracy cards
1 x tokens (progress, mythology, offering, snake, decrees)
1 x coins (3 compartments: 1s, 3s and 6s)
1 x holder (conflict- and Minerva-pawn)
1 x tray (military tokens, influence cubes)

boardgame.name: Le Beau Soleil d'Austerlitz
boardgame.description:
A two player grand tactical wargame depicting the Battle of Austerlitz fought in December 1805 between Napoleon and the Allied forces of Russia and Austria. Austerlitz is regarded as one of the classic Napoleonic battles and involves thousands of troops.

The battle was characterized by the early morning mist which concealed much of the dispositions and forces present.

The game system is innovative and requires players to devise a plan for the battle and accept restricted command. The battlefield is divided into areas rather than hexagons.

Units (counters) are divisions while command is command is activated at Corps level.

The game is playable solitaire as the command system creates discrete decision opportunities.

-description from developer

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: Beyond Tic Tac Ten
boardgame.description:
Beyond Tic Tac Ten is played on a 9x9 grid divided into nine 3x3 grids, as is the fake "Tic Tac Ten" game that inspired it. (This appeared in one of the fake ads in an earlier issue of GAMES.)

Players take turns marking an empty space. After the first move, each move must be made in the 3x3 corresponding to the position of the previous move in its 3x3 grid. E.g. if the first move is made in the upper right corner of its 3x3 grid, the second move must be made in the 3x3 grid in the upper right corner of the "board."

The first player to get three spaces in a line (a tic-tac-toe) in a single 3x3 grid wins. However, several variants are suggested, including one in which players try to get tic-tac-toes in three grids in a line, and both players can get a tic-tac-toe in the same grid

boardgame.name: Quoz
boardgame.description:
Quoz is played with a deck of eight suits each numbered 0-4, plus 12 numbered "Draw" cards and 12 "Quoz" cards.

On a turn a player plays two cards with matching number or suit, optionally accompanied by a Draw card. The next player to play is determined by the rank of the cards played (higher if different) - count that many players around the table. If it ends on the current player they choose who plays next.

Instead of playing a pair, a player may draw a card or play a Quoz card, which forces the previous player to also play a Quoz card. If they can't they collect all played cards and also draw cards as indicated by any Draw cards played. (Players may also have to collect cards if they can't play a pair under some circumstances.)

When a player is out of cards everyone else scores the value of their remaining cards. Low score when someone reaches 200 points wins.

boardgame.name: The Death Bed
boardgame.description:
From the description:

A demon-possessed bed that slowly drains resting PCs of their vitality. A great tool for the sadistic GM.

boardgame.name: The Entombed
boardgame.description:
From the description:

A sneaky trap and an unforgiving misery for unsuspecting dungeon delvers. PCs should never play with dead things.

boardgame.name: Die lustige Zwölf
boardgame.description: At the beginning of the game, each player places 10 coins on space 6. The players roll two dice and places 5 coins on the space with the rolled number if the space is empty. If not, he wins the 5 coins from this space. On the roll of a 6, five coins are payed every time. If a 12 is rolled, the player wins the game and all coins on the board.
boardgame.boardgamepublisher: Verlag von Auerbachs Deutschem Kinder Kalender

boardgame.name: Escapade
boardgame.description:
Escapade is played on a oblong hexagonal grid board using 13 pieces for each player, one of which is marked as a General. The other pieces are Guards.

The General and six Guards for each player start on the board, with the other six Guards as off-board reserves. On a turn a player may place a Guard from their reserve on any empty space, or they may move a piece on the board any number of empty spaces in a straight line.

A Guard is captured if an enemy piece is moved so that is directly between two enemy pieces. A General is captured if enemy pieces occupy all its adjacent spaces.

The object of the game is to move one's General to the goal area on the opposite edge of the board. One can also win by capturing the opposing General or lose if all the spaces in your target goal area become occupied.

boardgame.name: Youdunnit
boardgame.description:
Youdunnit is a solo journaling RPG. It is a game about deception and the claustrophobic dread of guilt and fear. It is a murder mystery in which you are the murderer.

Youdunnit was created as part of the Wretched & Alone jam, using the Wretched & Alone SRD, and is inspired by the likes of Agatha Christie's Poirot and Rian Johnson's Knives Out.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Operation: Cat Chat
boardgame.description:
Operation: Cat Chat is a game about being quarantined in an apartment with no internet and only your cat for company. It is a game about loneliness, connection, and what goes on in your cat’s mind.

Desperate for companionship, you decide to do what no one has done yet: learn to speak Cat. There’s no time like the present. Besides, what else are you going to do?

To play Operation: Cat Chat, you will need one six-sided die, a standard deck of cards, ten tokens that your cat likes, a recording method, and most importantly, a cat that can tolerate you.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: ASL Comp: GWASL X – Slavic Warriors: Serbian WW1
boardgame.description:
Serbia was blamed for the start of World War I following the assassination of Archduke Franz-Ferdinand in Sarajevo. Yet the Serbs would enjoy the first Allied victory of the war, after they drove the Austro-Hungarians out of the town of Sabac on 19 August 1914. Before they could, however, civilians were rounded up in the town and massacred. On the 5 October 1914, Austria launched their offensive against Serbia. The Serbian Army, weakened by Typhus, couldn’t hold out and the capital, Belgrade, was evacuated on the 9th. Two days later, Bulgaria declared war on Serbia, hoping to annex the Serb possession of Macedonia. By the 24th, the Bulgarians had driven a wedge between the Serb army and the Allied armies in Greece attempting to come to their aid. The Serbs fought with courage, but found their army critically low on ammunition stocks. With defeat staring them in the face, over 200,000 soldiers and civilians fled over the rugged mountains and into Albania. Many were evacuated by sea to the island of Corfu, in what would stand as the world’s largest evacuation by sea until the ‘miracle at Dunkirk’ in 1940. Surviving Serbian soldiers made their way to Greece, and remained in uniform to serve in the Yugoslav Division of Serbs, Croats, Macedonians, Montenegrins and Slovenes. When Bulgaria surrendered on 30 September 1918, Serb, Yugoslav, French and British forces united to drive the Austrians and Germans out of Serbia.

Ownership of ASL-RB, GWASL 1 and all preceding GWASL modules required to play.

Scenarios:

Delay Before The Drina - Podrinje, Serbia, August 12th 1914
Kosaningrad - Tekeris, Serbia, August 15th 1914
Mounted Clash - Tekeris, Serbia, August 16th 1914
In The Valley Of Jadar - Sabac, Serbia, August 16th 1914
Back Across The Drina - Cer, Serbia, August 17th 1914
The Liberation Of Sabac - Sabac, Serbia, August 24th 1914
The Youngest Corporal - Cer, Serbia, August 14th 1914
The Battle of Kolubara - Serbia, November 18th 1914

boardgame.name: Make a Wretched Game
boardgame.description:
These documents include everything you need to make a quick and easy Wretched Jam game! All you need is a cover image, a concept, a few paragraphs describing your concept, and card prompts, and I've done the rest!

Now featuring three formats!

Statement size 5.5" by 8.5" portrait
Letter size 11" by 8.5" landscape
Letter size 8.5" by 11" portrait
If you've been hesitant about joining Wretched Jam, hopefully this will at least help you get started!

To use one of these documents, open it, go to File and select "Make a Copy" from the drop down menu. This will give you a copy of the document that you can edit to your heart's content!

Good luck!!

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Murder Island
boardgame.description:
Murder Island is a solo journaling game using the Wretched & Alone SRD. It is played using a pack of cards, a tumbling block tower, tokens, and one six-sided die.


You are trapped on an island for killers.

The law says it is immoral to make an innocent person carry out the death penalty. Your kind are not wanted in the prison system, reform is not something they believe you capable of. They cannot kill you, so instead they make you disappear.

There is an island with the sole purpose of punishing killers. Food is limited. Weapons are plentiful. No land is within sight.

There is no escape from Murder Island.

You have been convicted of murder, although you’ve never killed anyone in your life. Your survival is unlikely. The killers far outmatch you in experience.

If you want to leave the island and resume a normal life it will mean proving your innocence.

The chances of doing this are slim. You will likely be murdered before gathering the evidence to set you free.

You could use your conviction to your advantage. Embrace it. Kill the others on the island. With enough time and murder you will have a reputation big enough for the others to leave you alone.

Yet, if you do choose to murder anyone on the island you won't get an opportunity to prove your innocence.

You are not prepared for this. You are likely to die, but you refuse to do nothing.

Which route will you choose?

boardgame.name: Five Blue Dragons
boardgame.description:
You play as a Destroyer, one who was born and raised to violently oppress others to maintain the System of Power your people created to safeguard their dominance. To stop yourself from causing further damage, you have entered the spirit world to sever your spirit from its five attachments to the System. Guarding the attachments are five blue dragons, spiritual embodiments of the reasons motivating you cling to Destruction. You must defeat all these dragons if you hope to achieve your goal.

This game is played with the following materials:

1 six-sided die (1d6)
10 double-sided tokens, such as coins
1 standard 52-card deck
A journal or electronic writing space


The main inspiration for this game was the T.V. show Avatar: The Last Airbender, which features a subplot of Fire Nation exiles trying to stop themselves from doing more damage to everyone around them. The question this game seeks to answer is: what does the pursuit of moral accountability require from a person who has committed unforgivable acts of violence? This is a game about confronting the ugliness of your past and present, not to find personal redemption, but to fulfill the obligation to change your future.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Spy: An Original Strategy Game
boardgame.description:
Spy is played on a 11x11 grid with 20 spaces designated as cities. There are five tiles in each of four colors, numbered 1-5, which are randomly placed on the cities at the start of the game.

Each player has four spies: one large, one medium, and two small. On a turn a player either places a spy on an empty edge space or move a spy any number of empty spaces orthogonally. A spy can end its move on a space with a smaller enemy spy, which is placed one space away in the direction the moving spy came from.

When four of the black tiles spaces are occupied those tiles are taken. The blue tiles are next, etc. The fifth tile in a color can be taken by any spy landing on its space.

When there is just one tile left the game ends. Players score the values of their tiles, plus a ten-point bonus for collecting three or four of the same number.
